data.title: Fifa confirms Nordic broadcast deals for 2026 World Cup
data.meta_description: Contracts ensure all 80 matches will be shown on free-to-air networks.
data.text:
Rights go to DR and TV2 in Denmark, YLE and MTV in Finland, TV2 and NRK in Norway, and SVT and TV4 in Sweden

Contracts complete Fifa rights cycle in region after last year’s Women’s World Cup deals

Fifa, soccer’s global governing body, has finalised its broadcast partnerships in the Nordic territories for the 2026 World Cup.

All the deals are with free-to-air networks, either public service or commercial broadcasters, with the contracts going to DR and TV2 in Denmark, YLE and MTV in Finland, TV2 and NRK in Norway, and SVT and TV4 in Sweden.

2023 Women’s World Cup to be aired by Viaplay as Nent picks up Nordic rights

Having agreed deals for the 2023 Women’s World Cup with Nordic Entertainment (Nent) covering Scandinavia, and Finnish state broadcaster YLE, Fifa has now completed its rights cycle in the region.

The contracts ensure that all 80 matches from the 2026 event, being hosted in the US, Mexico and Canada, will be aired live in each territory, with key matches shown on primary channels to maximise reach. With the tournament expanded to 48 teams, the deals are the largest in terms of live matches for any World Cup.

Jean-Christophe Petit, Fifa director of media rights and content services, said: “The expanded Fifa World Cup 2026 in North America is set to be an unforgettable event for football fans everywhere. We are pleased to be able to extend our partnership with the leading Nordic broadcasters, who provide strong platforms to ensure the best possible viewing experience for the largest audience.”
